results.title: The Astronaut
results.creator_credit: Beyond Productions, Film Finance Corporation Australia, Alan Hall and Peter Charley
results.brief_description: In 1998 the Space Shuttle “Endeavour” left Earth with a crew of seven - six American astronauts and one Russian cosmonaut to join the aging space shuttle Mir. On board was astronaut Andy Thomas, a space engineer born in Australia who trained in Russia to prepare for the mission. His stay on Mir would be for 4 1/2 months and his main function was to be the subject of research on the psychological and physiological effects of being in space. This research was used in developing the International Space Station Program; 15 nations working together to construct a permanently occupied laboratory in space.

results.title: The Astonishing Ashtons
results.creator_credit: John Moore Productions, John Moore and Lisa Jane Wallace
results.brief_description: For 150 years Ashton’s Circus has criss-crossed Australia, battling floods, high winds and outback roads to bring the magic of the circus to rural and city dwellers alike. This documentary goes behind the greasepaint and spectacle of the circus to provide an insight into the lives of the circus performers and other personnel.

results.title: The Astonished heart
results.creator_credit: Gainsborough Pictures, Antony Darnborough and Terence Fisher
results.brief_description: Noel Coward appears in this film he adapted from one of the nine one-act plays that make up the repertoire of his 1936 “Tonight at 8.30”. This repertoire included a diverse mix of song, dance and drama and was presented as a triple bill to showcase the talents of Coward and Gertrude Lawrence. This film concerns the emotional upheaval experienced by three friends who attempt to solve the problem by intellect. Psychiatrist Dr Christian Faber (Noel Coward) and his wife, Barbara (Celia Johnson) have begun to take each other for granted in their marriage. Christian begins an affair with Barbara’s best friend Leonora (Margaret Leighton). The affair is discovered by Barbara and the three avoid hurting one another over the issue. Christian is affected more deeply however, viewing his actions as a failure to meet his own moral and professional standards. Also starring Joyce Carey, Graham Payne, Amy Veness, Ralph Michael and Michael Hordern. Noel Coward also composed the musical score.

results.title: The Assam Garden
results.creator_credit: Moving Picture Company, Channel Four, Nigel Stafford-Clark and Mary McMurray
results.brief_description: An English woman is left alone following the death of her husband. She struggles to maintain the unusual garden he has created when they returned to England after many years of living in India. A brief encounter with an Indian woman from the neighbouring estate leads to the two women working together to bring the garden to its full glory. Even though they are from vastly different cultural and social backgrounds, a friendship gradually forms. Along the way, the film examines the institution of marriage and the problems of bereavement and loneliness. Stars Deborah Kerr and Madhur Jaffrey Rated: G

results.title: The Asphalt jungle
results.creator_credit: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Arthur Hornblow and John Huston
results.brief_description: Sam Jaffe plays a criminal mastermind, who, on his release from prison, develops a plan for executing the world’s biggest jewel heist. He assembles a crack team of thieves to assist him including wise-guy Sterling Hayden who is looking for one big chance at making money so he can escape the filth of New York City. Around a conventional film noir plot, John Huston fashions a stunning mise-en-scene that investigates the continuing shifting alliances and conflicts within the criminal underworld. Hayden makes a convincing noir hero and the supporting cast, including a young Marilyn Monroe, is uniformly excellent. Brilliantly lit and filmed, and with a taut script, “The Asphalt Jungle” is one of Huston’s best films; a classic example of a film that celebrates and challenges the conventions of the noir/gangster genre. Based on the novel by W.R. Burnett.

results.title: The Ascent = Voskhozhdenie
results.brief_description: In the bitter cold winter of 1942, two partisan guerillas hunting for food are captured by Nazi troops. Locked up in a cell with three other peasants awaiting execution - a young girl, a mother and an old man - they face the tortured choice between collaboration or martyrdom. Filmed in illuminating black and white which recalls the poetics of silent Soviet cinema, in the frozen landscapes of Belorussia, “The Ascent” offers a passionate testament to the spiritual redemption possible through struggle and faith. In exploring compassionately the nature of collaboration and betrayal and in being an explicitly Christian allegory, the film was a controversial landmark of the Soviet “new wave”. Based on a novella by Vassil Bakov the film was the penultimate work of Shepitko, one of the leading women directors of inter- national cinema in the seventies. Winner of the Golden Bear at Berlin in 1977.

results.title: The Artist was a woman: women artists, 1550-1950
results.brief_description: A comprehensive and chronological review of the work of known women artists over four hundred years from the Renaissance to mid-twentieth century. Germaine Greer comments upon the research undertaken and the difficulties involved in locating works of the women artists. Questions the way in which art history has been written. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: The Artist speaks: Kenneth Armitage
results.brief_description: Kenneth Armitage, the young British sculptor, discusses his work. Examples of Armitage’s work, mostly human figures; his London studio; his collection of photographs and cuttings; how an idea from a photograph is worked on through sketches to the plaster statue ready for casting.

results.title: The Artist as social critic; visionary
results.creator_credit: Center for Humanities, John G. Danza, Jim Maguire, Leslie Ann Nathan and Eve Cotton
results.brief_description: The first half of this program shows how painters have expressed their ideas about relationships between people, vice, injustice, human folly and achievement. It includes examples of social criticism by Goya, Hogarth, Rivera, David and Shahn. The painter as visionary is examined in the works of Blake, Bosch, Dali, de Chirico and Klee in the second section.
